Centerville, Utah

Centerville: View West from Centerville Ridge Trail

Centerville: Founders Park, located next to city hall, was rennovated in early 2005.

Centerville: View of Centerville's Parrish Lane from the East Mountains with The Great Salt Lake in the distance.

Centerville: This sign, located just off I-15, welcomes visitors to Centerville. In the distance lies the Centerville Business Park - the centerpiece of the Centerville Marketplace.

Earthquake activity:

Centerville-area historical earthquake activity is significantly above Utah state average. It is 2137% greater than the overall U.S. average.

On 8/18/1959 at 06:37:13, a magnitude 7.7 (7.7 UK, Class: Major, Intensity: VIII - XII) earthquake occurred 259.3 miles away from the city center, causing $26,000,000 total damage

On 10/3/1915 at 06:52:48, a magnitude 7.6 (7.6 UK) earthquake occurred 296.1 miles away from Centerville center

On 10/28/1983 at 14:06:06, a magnitude 7.3 (6.2 MB, 7.3 MS, 7.0 MW) earthquake occurred 238.9 miles away from the city center, causing 2 deaths (2 shaking deaths) and 3 injuries, causing $15,000,000 total damage

On 3/28/1975 at 02:31:05, a magnitude 6.2 (6.1 MB, 6.0 MS, 6.2 ML, Class: Strong, Intensity: VII - IX) earthquake occurred 81.1 miles away from the city center

On 3/18/2020 at 13:09:31, a magnitude 5.7 (5.7 MW, Depth: 7.4 mi, Class: Moderate, Intensity: VI - VII) earthquake occurred 16.0 miles away from the city center

On 12/21/1932 at 06:10:09, a magnitude 7.2 (7.2 UK) earthquake occurred 369.9 miles away from Centerville center

Magnitude types: body-wave magnitude (MB), local magnitude (ML), surface-wave magnitude (MS), moment magnitude (MW)

2003 - 2018 National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) incidents

Based on the data from the years 2003 - 2018 the average number of fire incidents per year is 20. The highest number of fires - 38 took place in 2011, and the least - 1 in 2005. The data has a rising trend.

When looking into fire subcategories, the most reports belonged to: Outside Fires (48.3%), and Structure Fires (25.7%).
